The School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) admits students with a wide range of academic backgrounds, including biology, chemistry, geology, physics, mathematics, engineering, and meteorology. SoMAS accepts students with a B.S. degree into both the M.S. and Ph.D. programs. Students can also be admitted with an M.S. degree into the Ph.D. program. The admissions committee evaluates applicants based on their entire record, including: ...academic preparation and performance as demonstrated through course work, GPA and GRE scores (if submitted), personal statements of purpose, and letters of recommendation. We place particular emphasis on previous research experience. Required Application Materials include: Stony Brook University Graduate School Application, Application Fee, Three Letters of Recommendation, One Official Transcript from each university you have attended, Statement of Purpose, and a Curriculum Vitae (CV) / Resume. The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test is no longer required for admission to the SoMAS graduate program.

Applicants must have a bachelor's degree in marine biology, biology, animal science, or a related field with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. Prerequisites: a C or better in introductory biology, introductory chemistry, introductory physics, and calculus.

Admission to the graduate program in Materials Science and Engineering requires a bachelor's degree in an engineering discipline or in the physical sciences. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 is required, along with three letters of recommendation. The GRE General Test is waived for the MS program.

Applicants must hold a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university. They should have a strong background in mathematics, including multivariable calculus, linear algebra and probability theory, and some computer programming experience. Admission is based on a student’s prior academic performance, GRE scores, letters of recommendation, and the personal statement. Required documents include the Graduate School application, three letters of recommendation, transcripts of all college/university work, a personal statement, and GRE scores. A résumé is strongly recommended.

Application for admission should be made through the Graduate School online application system. Besides the materials requested by the Graduate School, the applicant should submit the following:
1. A personal statement. This statement should explain the applicant’s interest in mathematics and describe his/her background in mathematics beyond the minimum requirements for admission. The statement can also be used to explain any special circumstances.
2. Three letters of recommendation. The letters should be written by mathematics professors who are familiar with the applicant’s abilities and know the applicant well. At least two letters should be from professors at the institution from which the applicant will receive his/her most recent degree. The letters should specifically address the applicant’s suitability for graduate study in mathematics.
3. The General GRE is not required. However, we strongly recommend that the applicant take the general GRE test and have the score reported. A high score in the quantitative part is an asset for the application.
4. The GRE Mathematics Subject test is not required. However, we recommend that applicants take this test, and a high score is a definite asset for the application.
5. TOEFL scores for international applicants.

For admission to graduate study in the Mathematics Department, a student must have a bachelor's degree in mathematics or a related field from an accredited college or university. An applicant's record must indicate a superior grasp of undergraduate mathematics. There is no specific requirement on credit hours but a typical applicant has completed a full year of analysis and abstract algebra with distinction. Students who do not meet these requirements are advised to enroll as non-matriculated students to take any necessary undergraduate courses.

Admission to the Ph.D. program is based primarily on the applicant's undergraduate record in mathematics, letters of recommendation, and scores on the Graduate Record Examinations (GRE). At least six semesters of undergraduate mathematics with grades of A or B are required, including courses in advanced calculus or real analysis, abstract algebra, and linear algebra. Complex analysis and topology are also very desirable.

To be considered for admission into our graduate programs, the minimum qualifications are:

A Bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering, or a closely related field, from a nationally accredited institution.
A minimum undergraduate grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
International applicants who do not have an undergraduate degree from an English-speaking university are required to take the TOEFL or IELTS exam. The minimum TOEFL score for admission is 85 (Internet-based test). The minimum IELTS score for admission is 7.0.
For Fall 2024 admissions, the GRE exam will be optional for all M.S. and Ph.D. applicants.

All applicants must submit an online application to the Graduate School. Requirements include: An online application, application fee, transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended, three letters of recommendation, a statement of purpose, Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores, and TOEFL or IELTS scores for international applicants whose native language is not English. A resume is required. Successful applicants will generally have an undergraduate grade point average of at least 3.2 on a 4.0 scale, a combined verbal and quantitative GRE score of at least 310, and an analytical GRE writing score of at least 3.5. Students entering with a Bachelor's degree from a U.S. university are expected to have an ABET accredited degree. For the PhD program, entering students are normally expected to have a M.S. degree in Mechanical Engineering or a closely related field. Highly qualified students with a B.S. degree and exceptional research potential can be admitted directly into the Ph.D. program.

Applicants to the program must hold an undergraduate degree with a minimum GPA of 3.0. In addition, candidates must have worked in a media-related field (journalism, advertising, public relations, film, marketing, publishing, corporate communications, etc.) for a minimum of two years OR have earned a graduate degree in a media-related field. Applications are accepted on a rolling basis, so candidates should consider applying early. A complete application consists of: An online application to the Graduate School, A 500-word personal statement outlining your professional experience and your career goals., A resume., Two letters of recommendation., Transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended., International students whose native language is not English must score at least a 90 on the TOEFL IBT exam.

We welcome applicants with a bachelor’s degree in any field. The application process is entirely online through the Stony Brook University Graduate School. All of the required materials should be uploaded with your application. In addition to a completed application form and fee, you will need to provide:

- Your resume.
- Official transcripts from every college or university you have attended, including community colleges and institutions where you may have taken only one or two classes. We accept unofficial transcripts for the review process. Please submit official transcripts upon admission to the program.
- A personal statement of 500-1,000 words that describes your interest in media management, career goals, and what you hope to get out of the program.
- Two letters of recommendation from professional or academic references. These should be requested and submitted electronically as part of the online application.

International students must also submit scores from the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). The minimum acceptable score is 90 for the Internet-based test. We require an official score report from ETS. The Stony Brook University code is 2548.

A complete application consists of the following:

Online Application
Application Fee
Unofficial Transcripts
Three Letters of Recommendation
Personal Statement (Statement of Purpose)
Curriculum Vitae/Resume
TOEFL or IELTS scores (for international applicants only)
A live or pre-recorded audition/interview is required of all applicants. For the pre-recorded option, the required audition repertoire can be uploaded via the application portal. Those who wish to complete a live audition should contact the music graduate office (mus-grad@stonybrook.edu).

Please submit a portfolio of scores and recordings (in any media format). The selection of works should show a clear demonstration of your current skills in the field of scoring and production. Three to five works of contrasting character are expected. Recordings must be of high quality. You should indicate your role in the creation of each piece. This can be uploaded via the application portal.

Bachelor's degree in music (or equivalent experience) from an accredited university or college; Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0; Online application; Portfolio of three original works submitted as either PDF scores, audio files, or video files with links; Statement of Purpose: A 500-word essay detailing your interest in the program and career goals; Three letters of recommendation from individuals who can attest to your academic and/or professional potential; Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended; Application fee.
Program name: Media Scoring and Production MM Online

Requirements:
An undergraduate degree from an accredited U.S. institution or the equivalent from a foreign institution.
Undergraduate GPA: No specific GPA is required, but a strong academic record is expected.
GRE Scores: GREs are not required.
Statement of Purpose describing the applicant’s academic interests and goals.
Writing Sample of at least ten pages.
Three letters of recommendation.
TOEFL for international students (see Graduate School requirements).
Resume or C.V.

A personal statement is required. A résumé is required. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. A PhD in physics, medical physics, or a closely related field (e.g., engineering, physical chemistry, or computer science) is required for admission. Prerequisite coursework required for consideration includes: Two semesters of calculus-based physics (e.g., mechanics, E&M, modern physics), Multivariable calculus, Differential equations, Upper-level undergraduate courses in electricity and magnetism, quantum mechanics, and classical mechanics are required.

The Medical Dosimetry program requires a Bachelor's degree from an accredited university. Applicants must have a cumulative GPA of at least a 3.0. Prerequisite coursework includes: Physics (two semesters with labs), Anatomy & Physiology (two semesters with labs), Pre-calculus, Medical Terminology, Oral and Written Communication. All prerequisite courses must have been completed with a grade of a C or better and within the past 10 years. ARRT certification in Radiation Therapy is required at the time of application. In addition to the online Graduate School application, the following supplemental materials must be submitted: Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended; Three letters of recommendation; Personal statement indicating interest in the program and career goals; Copy of ARRT certification in Radiation Therapy; Resume; Observation hours documentation (a minimum of 24 observation hours are required).

Baccalaureate degree, preferably in a physical or biological science, from an accredited college or university. Minimum cumulative grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Completion of the following prerequisite coursework from an accredited college or university: Mathematics (calculus) - one semester; Statistics - one semester; Physics (calculus-based) - two semesters with labs; Chemistry - two semesters with labs; Biology (with human focus) - two semesters with labs; English composition - one semester; Computer literacy - one semester. Prior clinical experience in radiation oncology is highly recommended but not required. The Medical Dosimetry Program does not require the GRE exam for admission.

A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university in meteorology or oceanography. Students with degrees in the basic sciences (physics, chemistry, mathematics) or engineering are also encouraged to apply provided they have taken courses in mathematics (through differential equations) and physics (through mechanics, heat, electricity, and magnetism). Your statement of purpose describing your interests and career goals is an important part of your application.

Official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended; Personal Statement; Three letters of recommendation; Curriculum Vitae/Resume; GRE General Test Scores: Optional; English Proficiency for International Applicants: TOEFL/IELTS/Duolingo; Completed online application and application fee.

Applicants to the Ph.D. program in Molecular and Cellular Biology (MCB), which comprises the graduate training tracks in Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology (MCP), Microbiology and Immunology (M&I), and Molecular Genetics and Microbiology (MGM) must apply through the Graduate Program in Molecular and Cellular Biology (MCB). For further information about the application process and requirements for the graduate program, please go to the MCB graduate program web page.

To be considered for admission to the doctoral program in Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology, applicants must have a bachelor’s degree in the life or physical sciences from an accredited college or university. This background should include one year each of general biology, general chemistry, organic chemistry and physics, and at least one semester of calculus. It is highly recommended that students also take physical chemistry and biochemistry. A grade point average of at least 3.0 is expected.

Research experience is highly desirable.

Letters of recommendation from at least three professors are required.

A statement of purpose describing the student’s background and career goals is required.

The GRE General Test is not required.

International students must take the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), and score at least 90 on the iBT test.

Applications for admission and financial support should be received by December 1 for admission the following fall. Only students applying for full-time work toward the PhD degree will be considered for admission.

For more information, visit the program website at: http://www.pharm.stonybrook.edu/pharmacology/grad_program

Admission to the graduate program in Molecular and Cellular Biology is based on a number of factors, including: Academic records (GPA), Letters of recommendation (at least three), Personal statement, Research experience
Program name: Molecular Cell and Developmental Biology PhD

Requirements:
The following materials are required for an application to the MFA in Film program:

Personal Statement: Submit a 750-1000 word personal statement addressing your artistic background and goals, filmmaking experience, and why you believe the Stony Brook/Killer Films MFA in Film is the right program for you.

Writing Sample: Submit one of the following: a feature-length screenplay (80-120 pages), two short screenplays (no more than 30 pages total), one-hour teleplay (45-65 pages), half-hour teleplay (25-35 pages), a full-length stage play, or a substantial piece of creative writing (short story, excerpt from a novel or novella).

Creative Portfolio: Submit links to up to three samples of your creative work as a director, writer/director, cinematographer, editor, producer or other key creative role. You may submit short films (no longer than 20 minutes), web series, feature films, or other video/film projects that you feel best represent your artistic sensibility. If a work is password protected, please provide the password.

Three letters of recommendation.

Résumé or Curriculum Vitae.

Transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended.

International applicants should review the Graduate School's requirements for English proficiency.

Application for admission to the MA in philosophy is made to the Graduate School. In addition to general Graduate School requirements, the Philosophy Department requires the following:

Three letters of recommendation
A writing sample
A statement of purpose

The GRE is not required.

In addition to the documents required by the Graduate School, the Department of Philosophy requires the following:

Online Application: You must complete the online application through the Graduate School.
Transcripts: Please upload unofficial transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions you have attended. Official transcripts will be required upon admission.
Letters of Recommendation: Three letters of recommendation are required. The most useful letters are from philosophy professors who know your work well.
Statement of Purpose: A statement of purpose is required.
Writing Sample: A writing sample is required. It should be a philosophy paper of approximately 15-25 pages in length (double-spaced).
GRE Scores: The GRE is not required for admission to our graduate program.
Application Fee: You must submit the application fee. Information about application fee waivers is here.
International Students: International applicants may also be required to submit TOEFL or IELTS scores. Please consult the Graduate School's website for specific requirements.

A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university. A minimum cumulative and prerequisite grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Completion of prerequisite courses. A minimum of 100 hours of volunteer or paid experience in a physical therapy setting is required. We recommend that applicants gain exposure to a variety of physical therapy settings (e.g., hospital, outpatient, rehabilitation, etc). Three references are required. It is strongly recommended that at least one reference be from a licensed physical therapist. The remaining references may be from a college professor and/or a work supervisor. Interviews are a required part of the admission process. Interviews are by invitation only.

1. Complete the on-line Graduate School application available at the Graduate School website: https://grad.stonybrook.edu/admissions/
2. Bachelor’s degree in any field from an accredited college or university.
3. Master’s degree or professional doctoral degree (DPT) in physical therapy or related field.
4. License to practice physical therapy in a state or territory of the US or the District of Columbia. If the applicant is an international student, graduation from a program determined to be equivalent to the first professional degree in physical therapy in the US is required.
5. Three letters of recommendation indicating potential for success in a PhD program. Recommendations from an academic instructor and a research mentor are encouraged.
6. Resume or curriculum vitae detailing clinical and/or research experiences.
7. Goal statement (1-2 pages) including short and long-term professional goals and how the PhD program in Physical Therapy at Stony Brook University will help to achieve those goals.
8. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. A minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale) is required for admission.
9. An interview with the PhD in Physical Therapy Admissions Committee.
10. All applicants from non-English speaking countries must take and submit scores for the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) or International English Language Testing System (IELTS). See the Graduate School's guidelines for minimum scores.
11. GRE: waived for Fall 2024 admissions.

The admission requirements below are the minimum requirements that all applicants must meet to be considered for this program.

GPA: 3.0
GRE General: Not Required
GRE Subject: Recommended
TOEFL iBT/IELTS: International students whose native language is not English are required to take the TOEFL iBT or IELTS exam. The minimum TOEFL iBT score is 85, and the minimum IELTS score is 6.5. For more information, see the Graduate School's English Proficiency Requirements.
Other Indicators of High Promise: Applicants should have completed the following prerequisite coursework with a letter grade of C or higher: three semesters of introductory physics, one semester of modern physics, one semester of classical mechanics, one semester of electricity and magnetism, one semester of quantum mechanics, one semester of thermal physics, two semesters of advanced physics lab, four semesters of calculus, and one semester of linear algebra. Students lacking a small portion of this preparation may still be admitted, but may be required to do some remedial work.

To be considered for admission to the graduate program in physics, students must have a bachelor's degree in physics or a related field with a strong physics content. The application should include: Transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended. Three letters of recommendation. Statement of purpose. Resume/CV. For international students for whom English is not their first language, a TOEFL or IELTS score is required by the Graduate School. The GRE general and physics subject tests are not required for admission, but can be submitted if the applicant wishes.

In addition to the general admission requirements of the Graduate School, the specific admission requirements for the Program in Biomedical Sciences are as follows:

1. A bachelor’s degree with an adequate foundation in biology, chemistry and mathematics.
2. Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended.
3. Three letters of recommendation from college faculty who can knowledgeably comment on your academic and research potential.
4. Statement of Purpose describing your reasons for applying to the graduate program, your previous research experience, and your future research interests and professional goals.
5. GRE General Test scores are not required.
6. For international students, TOEFL (or equivalent) scores may be required. Please refer to the Graduate School’s website for more information.

Application (through the Graduate School online portal)
Statement of Purpose
Three Letters of Recommendation
Transcripts from all previous institutions
GRE: Not required
Resume/CV
English Proficiency (for international students)
Writing Sample: Applicants should submit a writing sample of 5-10 pages (double-spaced). The sample should demonstrate the applicant’s ability to conduct research and write about a music-related topic at a graduate level. The writing sample may be a revised version of a paper written for an undergraduate course.
Teaching Video: Applicants should submit a video of 10-15 minutes in length showing the applicant teaching music to students in an individual or group setting.
Interview: Finalists will be contacted for an online interview.

Applicants to the MS program must have completed an undergraduate degree from an accredited university. A minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 is required for admission. The following materials must be submitted with your application: Transcripts, Three letters of recommendation, a Personal Statement describing your motivation to pursue a graduate degree in Prevention Science and Community Health and how this degree will help you to achieve your career goals, and a curriculum vitae or resume.
Program name: Prevention Science and Community Health MS

Requirements: Applicants to the PhD program must apply through SOPHAS, the centralized application service for public health. The application deadline is December 15th for admission the following fall. Applicants to the PhD in Prevention Science and Community Health must hold a bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university. A master’s degree in Public Health or a related field is preferred, but not required. The following materials are required to complete your SOPHAS application: Curriculum vitae (CV) or resume; Personal Statement: A personal statement describing your interest in prevention science and community health, career goals, and how our PhD program will help you achieve those goals; Three letters of recommendation submitted through SOPHAS from individuals who can attest to your capacity for doctoral-level work. Ideally, recommenders will have a PhD and have known you in a research or academic capacity; Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended. Transcripts for any coursework completed outside of the U.S. will need to be evaluated by World Education Services (WES); Writing sample: An academic or professional writing sample of which you are the sole author (e.g., a master's thesis, peer-reviewed publication, or report). Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores are NOT required.
Program name: Prevention Science and Community Health PhD

Requirements: Applicants must submit the Graduate School online application, an application fee, a Statement of Purpose, transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, three letters of recommendation, and a resume. The GRE General Test is optional for Spring 2025 and Fall 2025 applicants. International students must also submit TOEFL or IELTS scores.

Applicants to this program must have a bachelor's degree with a minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0. In addition to the online application and application fee, applicants must submit: Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. A current resume. A personal statement that addresses the applicant's reasons for pursuing this certificate. One letter of recommendation. An interview with a faculty member may be required.

The School of Nursing participates in a Centralized Application Service for Nursing Programs (NursingCAS). Applicants will apply online through the NursingCAS portal. To learn more about the application process and requirements, please visit the NursingCAS website at www.nursingcas.org.

Admission Requirements
* Master’s or doctoral degree in nursing from a nationally accredited program.
* National certification as a Nurse Practitioner (Adult, Family, Pediatric, Adult-Gerontology Primary Care, or Women's Health) or Certified Nurse Midwife.
* New York State license as a Registered Nurse and Nurse Practitioner (or eligible).
* Minimum GPA of 3.0.
* One year of clinical experience as a nurse practitioner is preferred.
* Three letters of recommendation.
* A comprehensive essay (see essay questions below).
* Resume.
* Successful completion of a college-level statistics course with a grade of C or better.
* Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended.
* Interview with faculty.
Program name: Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner Certificate

Requirements:
Admission to the graduate program in Psychology is highly competitive. The Department of Psychology typically admits 15-20 students a year out of an applicant pool of over 600. Admission is for the Ph.D. program only.

A Bachelor’s degree in psychology or a related discipline. Undergraduate courses in experimental psychology and statistics are also highly recommended.

GRE General test is not required for admission. A Statement of Purpose detailing your specific interests, career goals, and experience relevant to the area to which you are applying. Three letters of recommendation are also required.

A minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.0. Official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended. A bachelor’s degree in psychology or a related field (e.g., education, social work). At least 15 credits of psychology coursework including a course in statistics and a course in research methods or experimental psychology. Preferred coursework also includes a course in learning and a course in applied behavior analysis. A personal statement describing the applicant’s interest in applied behavior analysis, career goals, and reasons for applying to this program. Three letters of recommendation. A curriculum vitae (CV)/resume. The GRE is not required for admission to this program.

To be considered for admission, applicants must have a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university with a minimum grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Applicants must also submit a completed application form, official undergraduate transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, a personal statement and two letters of recommendation.

Admission to the Master of Public Administration (M.P.A.) degree program is based on a comprehensive review of each applicant’s materials. We seek candidates with a strong academic record and a demonstrated commitment to public service who will contribute to a diverse and dynamic learning environment.

Applicants must have the following:

- A Bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university.
- A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0.
- Official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended.
- Personal statement: All applicants are required to submit a personal statement (750-1,000 words) discussing their interest in public service, professional goals, and how they believe the Stony Brook M.P.A. will help them achieve these goals. The personal statement is an opportunity to highlight any relevant experiences, skills, or perspectives that may not be fully captured in other application materials.
- Three letters of recommendation: Letters should be from faculty or other professionals who can speak to the applicant’s academic abilities, professional accomplishments, and potential for success in a graduate program.
- Resume or curriculum vitae (CV): Applicants must submit a current resume or CV detailing their work experience, volunteer activities, and any relevant skills or accomplishments.
- GRE scores: GRE scores are not required for admission to the M.P.A. program.
- Writing sample (optional): Applicants may submit a writing sample (e.g., a research paper, policy brief, or professional report) to demonstrate their analytical and writing skills. The writing sample should be no more than 15 pages.
- English proficiency: International applicants must demonstrate proficiency in English. See the Graduate School's requirements for more information.

Applicants to the Master of Public Administration (MPA) program must meet the following criteria:

A bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university.
An undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 or higher.
Three letters of recommendation.
A statement of purpose.
A current résumé.
Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.
The GRE is not required.
An interview with the Program Director may be required.

Required application materials include: official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended, three letters of recommendation, a personal statement describing your interest in public health and your career goals, and a resume or curriculum vitae. GRE scores are optional for Certificate applicants.

To apply for admission to the Master of Public Health (MPH) program, you must submit an application through the Schools of Public Health Application Service (SOPHAS). The following documents are required for an application to be considered complete: Online SOPHAS application; Official Transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended; Three letters of recommendation; A statement of purpose or personal statement; A resume or curriculum vitae. The Program in Public Health has suspended the GRE requirement for all MPH applicants for the Fall 2024 admissions cycle. Applicants can choose whether to submit their GRE scores with their application.

Applicants to the Master of Public Health program are required to have:

- A bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university.
- A cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher.
- At least one college-level math course (e.g. algebra, pre-calculus or calculus) and one college-level basic science course (e.g., biology, chemistry, or physics) with a grade of C or better.
- Application submitted through the Schools of Public Health Application Service (SOPHAS).
- Three letters of recommendation.
- Resume or curriculum vitae.
- Personal Statement: a 500-1500 word personal statement of purpose that describes your interest in public health, your career goals, and how the Stony Brook MPH program will help you achieve these goals.
- Official transcripts from all post-secondary schools attended.
- Application fee.

To be admitted to the dual-degree program, students must be admitted separately by both the Master of Arts in Public Policy (MAPP) and the Master of Public Health (MPH) programs. Application requirements for admission include a bachelor's degree, a strong academic record (the MAPP program recommends a minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0), official transcripts from every college/university attended, three letters of recommendation, a personal statement/statement of purpose, and a resume or curriculum vitae. The GRE is not required for the MAPP program and is optional for the MPH program.

The following are required for admission to the Master of Science in Public Health degree program:
1. A baccalaureate degree or its equivalent from an accredited college or university.
2. A minimum cumulative grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
3. Three letters of recommendation. At least two of the letters of recommendation should come from academic instructors who are able to assess the applicant’s potential for success in a graduate program.
4. Personal statement. A personal statement of approximately 1,000 words describing the applicant’s reason for pursuing a graduate degree in public health, interest in the chosen concentration, and both short- and long-term career goals. Applicants should highlight any experiences in public health (e.g., employment, volunteer, research, etc.).
5. A current resume or curriculum vitae.
6. Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores. Test must be taken within five years of the application date. Please note that GREs are waived for the Fall 2024 application cycle.
7. Official transcripts from all post-secondary schools attended.

All applications must include the following: Online application and fee; Unofficial transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities. Official transcripts will be required if you are offered admission; Three letters of recommendation; Statement of purpose; Resume; TOEFL or IELTS scores for all applicants whose native language is not English; Writing sample (see below for more details); GRE scores are not required.

A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university. A minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. A minimum of 18 credits in the liberal arts and sciences (i.e. social and behavioral sciences, humanities, natural sciences and math). A statistics course with a grade of C or better. Human or social service experience, preferably post-baccalaureate, paid or volunteer. Personal characteristics and qualifications suitable for the profession of social work.
Program name: Special Focus Area in Health Programs, Policies and Practice (MSW)

Requirements: Applicants must have a bachelor's degree from an accredited institution. They must also have a minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.00. Applicants should apply for this certificate program by submitting a School of Professional Development (SPD) application, which includes official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, a personal statement, and one letter of recommendation.
Program name: Teaching and Learning With Technology Certificate

Requirements: In addition to fulfilling the requirements for admission to the Graduate School, applicants must have completed an undergraduate major in English (or its equivalent, e.g. 36 credits of upper-division coursework in English). A cumulative grade point average of 3.0 or higher is required for admission, as is a 3.0 or higher in all English coursework. The following materials must be submitted through the online application system: Graduate School Application form, Two letters of recommendation, A statement of purpose, One official transcript from each college/university attended, A writing sample of 8-10 pages of academic writing on a literary topic, A curriculum vitae. The GRE general test is not required for admission to the English MAT program.

Applicants should have:
- A bachelor’s degree in one of the languages in which we offer certification: French, Italian, or Spanish.
- An overall GPA of 3.0 and a GPA of 3.0 in the major.
- A grade of B or better in a course on the structure of the target language (e.g., FRE 311, ITL 311, SPN 311 or equivalent).
- Proficiency in spoken and written English, and in the language of certification. All applicants must take the Oral Proficiency Interview (OPI) in their language of certification and achieve at least the advanced-low rating. They must also pass a Writing Proficiency Test (WPT).
- A minimum of 24 semester hours of upper-division courses in the target language. These courses should focus on language, literature, and culture.
- 12 credits of language study other than English and the target language (this requirement can be met by 4 years of one language in high school or 2 years each of two languages in high school or a combination of high school and college coursework).

Required application materials include:
- Unofficial transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended are required for the application review. Official transcripts are required upon acceptance into the program.
- 3 letters of recommendation
- Resume
- Personal statement in English
- A writing sample in the target language of about 250 words.

Standardized Tests:
- GRE is not required.
- For international applicants: Minimum TOEFL Score: 85 (iBT with 22 Speaking subscore); Minimum IELTS Score: 6.5 (Overall with 6.5 Speaking subscore); Minimum Duolingo Score: 115.

To be considered for admission, a student must have an undergraduate degree in mathematics or its equivalent: at least 36 credits of mathematics and related areas, including a year of calculus of one and several variables (AMS 161, 261 or MAT 132, 203 or similar), linear algebra (AMS 210 or MAT 211 or similar), and at least 18 credits of upper division mathematics courses, including courses on the foundations of analysis (MAT 319 or 320 or similar), and on the foundations of algebra (MAT 312 or 313 or similar). The cumulative GPA must be at least 3.0, and the GPA in mathematics and science must be at least 3.0.

Online Application to the Graduate School, including:

Résumé
A personal statement (about 2 pages) stating your purpose in undertaking graduate study in mathematics education.
Transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Unofficial transcripts can be uploaded to the online application for review purposes. If an offer of admission is made and accepted, official transcripts will be required.
Three letters of recommendation.
GRE scores are not required.
A TOEFL score of at least 90 (for the internet-based test) is required for all applicants from countries where English is not the primary language.

Admissions Requirements

- A bachelor's degree in biology, chemistry, earth science, or physics with a minimum GPA of 3.0 overall, and in the content area. A minimum of 36 credits in the content area is required. Students who need to fulfill additional science content courses may be able to take them as a non-matriculated student in the School of Professional Development.
- GRE general test. Students with a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher who also have a degree in the sciences (biology, chemistry, physics, earth science) from a U.S. college or university may request a GRE waiver. (Note: GRE requirement is currently suspended. It is not required for Spring or Fall 2024 admissions.)
- One year of college-level study of a foreign language with a grade of "C" or better (or equivalent).
- A course in developmental psychology/adolescent development is also required. Candidates who have not taken this course may be admitted, but will be required to take SPD's CEF 547: Human Growth and Development, or its equivalent, within the first two semesters of study.

Application Materials

To apply, candidates must submit the following:

- A completed online Graduate School application.
- Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.
- A personal statement that addresses the following question: "Why do you want to become a science teacher?" The statement will be evaluated on the basis of clarity, grammar, and syntax.
- Three letters of recommendation.
- GRE general test scores. (Note: GRE requirement is currently suspended. It is not required for Spring or Fall 2024 admissions.)
- A non-refundable application fee of $100.
- TOEFL/IELTS scores are required for applicants for whom English is not their first language.

Bachelor's degree with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. A major in history, political science, economics, anthropology, or geography or 30 credits in social studies, including 21 credits in history (including coursework in U.S. history and non-western history) and coursework in political science and economics. Completion of one year of college-level study of a foreign language with a grade of C or better. GRE or other standardized tests are not required for admission. Three letters of recommendation. A statement of purpose. New York State requires that all candidates for teacher certification pass a series of tests to become licensed. Candidates in the Social Studies Teacher Education program must pass the Content Specialty Test (CST) prior to student teaching. Résumé.

In addition to the Graduate School’s admission requirements, the following are required: A bachelor’s degree in engineering, natural sciences, or mathematics, with a minimum cumulative grade point average of 3.0. Appropriate work experience is considered. GRE general test is no longer required for applicants holding a degree from an ABET-accredited program in the U.S. All other applicants are required to take the GRE General Test (verbal, quantitative and analytical). The department does not set a minimum GRE test score. Three letters of recommendation. A personal statement clearly stating the applicant’s interest in this program. International applicants are required to take the TOEFL examination and must score at least 85 on the iBT.

The PhD Program in Technology, Policy, and Innovation is intended for those with a master’s degree from a recognized university. Students with exceptional undergraduate degrees will be considered on a case by case basis. Applicants for admission to the PhD program in Technology, Policy, and Innovation are required to submit the following credentials: An official application to the Graduate School. Official transcripts of all undergraduate and graduate courses. Three letters of recommendation. A comprehensive statement of purpose. For foreign students, a satisfactory score on the TOEFL examination is required (550 on the paper-based test or 213 on the computer-based test). The GRE is not required.
